image.altText: Derelict terrace houses covered in graffiti.

props.synopsis: With official estimates putting the number of vacant and derelict homes above 100,000 across Australia, local governments and property lawyers argue they could be part of the solution to Australia's apparent housing shortage.

title.children: Up to 140,000 homes are sitting empty. What could be done to get people living in them again?

image.altText: A girl sits on the floor hunched in a corner next to a cupboard, peering over her knees.

props.synopsis: The 45-year-old stepfather also abused the victim's young sisters. He will be sentenced in WA later this year, but the case has raised disturbing questions about children's safety.

title.children: Child abuse victim 'begged for help', but WA Department of Communities failed to act

image.altText: Joe Biden yells mouth wide open with his fist in the air at a podium.

props.synopsis: This past week was arguably the worst of Joe Biden's 2024 campaign. And it might have been one of Donald Trump's best.

title.children: Biden's bad night has become a worse week. And for Trump, things keep getting better

image.altText: A young woman wearing grey dress over black skivvy stands in front of a house, smiling with a mug in her hands

props.synopsis: Australian homes are notoriously cold in winter — draughty, with poor insulation, thin glass and inadequate heating. But there's a growing movement of people retrofitting their homes to make them cheaper to run and more comfortable year-round, while also reducing emissions.

title.children: Got an old, cold house like Laine's? Here are seven ways to make it warmer and cheaper

image.altText: Black and white photo of tobacco grading at Manjimup, 1952.

props.synopsis: The small WA town of Manjimup has long struggled to find an identity that sticks and, after the state government's timber industry shutdown, locals are asking: "What's next?"

title.children: From tobacco to cauliflowers to timber, where this WA town heads next is the million-dollar question

image.altText: A woman receives dialysis

props.synopsis: The state government has blamed COVID-19 and record floods for a lack of progress on its election pledge as Indigenous health leaders vent about a lack of consultation.

title.children: WA government walks away from pledge to build outback dialysis clinic before next election

image.altText: Two older men in gray suits look concerned

props.synopsis: The last week of parliament before the winter recess can often be messy — and this week proved to be no exception for either Anthony Albanese or Peter Dutton.

title.children: All eyes are on Payman's future with Labor, but Dutton has his own woes playing out behind closed doors

image.altText: A young woman wearing thin glasses, light red lipstick and a grey hijab looks to her right in closeup

props.synopsis: The West Australian senator has told colleagues she is seeking religious guidance on her next move but is expected to make a decision on quitting her party today.

title.children: Payman decision expected as caucus colleagues express concern over claims she was being guided by 'God'

image.altText: Brent Wyndham in a pale shirt, walking with lawyers.

props.synopsis: A coronial inquiry has heard police internal affairs found an officer failed four times to follow the WA Police use of force policy when shooting an armed Indigenous woman in the Mid West city of Geraldton in 2019.

title.children: Officer failed to negotiate with Indigenous woman JC before fatally shooting her in Geraldton, inquest hears

image.altText: bruce lehrmann walking outside court

props.synopsis: The 29-year-old faces two counts of rape, alleged to have occurred in Toowoomba, west of Brisbane, in October 2021.

title.children: Former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann's lawyers expected to submit 'no case to answer' at rape charges hearing

image.altText: Entrance to Harry Perkins Medical Institute in Perth.

props.synopsis: The Harry Perkins Institute of Medical Research in Perth confirms it is investigating a major cyber security incident.

title.children: Major cyber security incident confirmed at leading WA medical research group, Harry Perkins Institute

image.altText: A close up image of a male teen with his hand over his face looking at a mobile phone

props.synopsis: Female teachers are being sworn at, sexually harassed and physically threatened in high schools by male students. They say young men are bringing the misogynistic ideas of Andrew Tate and other online influencers into the classroom.

title.children: 'Disgusting and disturbing': Why some female teachers are leaving the profession

image.altText: A woman stands in a room with bookshelves behind her. She is looking up and has her hands on her hips.

props.synopsis: An audit of Queensland Fertility Group semen samples frozen before 2020 found thousands to be at high risk of misidentification because of a lack of double witnessing, a report by the state's health ombudsman says.

title.children: Major IVF clinic accused of using the wrong sperm asked to destroy thousands of samples

image.altText: A number of beauty products placed on a vibrant pink display stand.

props.synopsis: Australian cosmetics giant MCoBeauty has attracted global attention for its strikingly similar beauty dupes, but the company has kept the details of its product development process out of the spotlight — until now.

title.children: We asked MCoBeauty to explain how they dupe cosmetics. They gave us a step-by-step guide

image.altText: A man standing on a balcony deck, looking over a swimming pool with large arid mountains and a blue sky beyond the propety

props.synopsis: Igal uses the online platform Booking.com to advertise his holiday apartment. But human rights lawyers want the practice banned and allege Booking.com is breaking international law.

title.children: It's a home with a serious view. But human rights lawyers say Booking.com should be banned from advertising it

image.altText: A drink on a bar with a few wedges of lime in it.

props.synopsis: Despite anecdotal information suggesting spiking is reasonably common, only seven people went to court charged with unlawful drink spiking in Queensland between July 2021 and May 2024.

title.children: 'This wasn't a rape, we can't test you': Woman says she was denied drink spiking test at Brisbane hospital

image.altText: Remote control dozers are helping seal the burning Grosvenor Coal Mine.

props.synopsis: Queensland's largest underground coal mine is on fire up to half a kilometre below ground. Remote control technology is helping in an around-the-clock race to seal the mine and avoid further explosions.

title.children: A coal mine fire has been burning for five days in central Queensland. There is only one way to put it out

image.altText: Sunak speaks in front of a lectern emblazoned with the slogan "stop the boats".

props.synopsis: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has spent years fighting to send asylum seekers to an offshore detention facility. Not only has the plan failed, it's likely to help sweep his government out of office.

title.children: Britain's Tories copied Australia's 'stop the boats' policy. Now they're set to lose the election

image.altText: A person holds a bag of nitazenes powder.

props.synopsis: There are fears of more overdoses as nitazenes infiltrate Australia's underground drug supply, with occasional recreational drug users warned the synthetic opioid is being found in drugs like cocaine.

title.children: Nitazenes are coming into Australia from India and China. Their effects are deadly

image.altText: A stylish woman in a beige coat and jeans holds a large black handbag.

props.synopsis: Handbags, backpacks and other work bags may be tax deductible providing they comply with some rather strict rules.

title.children: Yes, you can claim a tax deduction for a bag — as long as you follow these rules

image.altText: Stephen Pokrywka in a flannel shirt, holding his young grandchildren

props.synopsis: An Australian resident of more than four decades is deported to the United Kingdom after his visa was cancelled due to a drug conviction, with a last-minute appeal rejected by the Federal Court.

title.children: Stephen Pokrywka has been deported, and wasn't allowed to see his Australian family in person before he left

image.altText: A professionally-dressed woman in a grey blazer stands on the property of a one-storey suburban home

props.synopsis: Landlords in New South Wales say a looming policy change by the state government to ban a practice known as "no-grounds evictions" will erode the rights of property owners and reduce the amount of rental stock on the market.

title.children: 'It's the landlord's property': Warning planned rental protections go too far

image.altText: A hooded man holds a laptop computer as cyber code is projected on him in this illustration picture

props.synopsis: The hackers behind a major cyber attack on the Indonesian government issue a surprise apology and offer to release the stolen data.

title.children: Hackers promise 'keys for free' after locking up Indonesian government data centres

image.altText: A pig and human figures painted on a rock wall in red pigment.

props.synopsis: The discovery of red pigment paintings daubed on the walls of a secluded Sulawesi cave about 51,000 years ago also provides the oldest evidence of our species, Homo sapiens, in the region, according to a new study.

title.children: Ancient hunting scene in an Indonesian cave is the oldest-known evidence of visual storytelling

image.altText: A group of insectoid like creatures swimming away from a cloud of ash

props.synopsis: Scientists were taught that they would never find fossils in volcanic rock but a recent discovery shows the complete opposite.

title.children: How the discovery of a 509-million-year-old fossil flipped palaeontology on its head

image.altText: Man sits in driver's seat.

props.synopsis: Wall Street has hit fresh highs off the back of major tech stocks, with the Australian share market expected to follow. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASIC report fallout continues, while ASX to rise as Tesla and Nvidia push up tech indexes on Wall Street

image.altText: A woman with short black hair sips a coffee.

props.synopsis: A steep hike in visa fees is pushing current and prospective international students to consider other universities outside of Australia.

title.children: Hike in visa fees pushes international students to look beyond Australia

image.altText: A middle aged white woman without a right arm sits outside in a motorised wheelchair, wearing a striped shirt and big glasses.

props.synopsis: Disability groups say federal budget funding cuts will leave them less able to support vulnerable Australians as the government rolls out widespread changes to services and supports.

title.children: Disability organisations facing redundancies as community prepares for royal commission and NDIS changes

image.altText: Joe Biden with one hand raised partially covered by dark shadows.

props.synopsis: Joe Biden has jet lag. Joe Biden has a cold. Joe Biden was over-prepared. Joe Biden was under-prepared. Joe Biden has a stutter. Defenders of the president have trotted out plenty of excuses since last week's catastrophic first debate against Donald Trump. But should they replace him?

title.children: Should Joe Biden step down? Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson and Jimmy Carter have a warning

image.altText: Two men stand behind a bar

props.synopsis: After swapping life in the city for sheep and a vegetable garden, the couple is running a thriving gin distillery. Demographers believe more people in their age bracket could make the move to country areas as lower property prices offer more opportunities.

title.children: Will and Michael have found a full life in country Australia. Can other millennials follow in their footsteps?

image.altText: A cyclist sits up in the saddle, grinning widely with his arms spread wide as he coasts past the finish line.

props.synopsis: The "Manx Missile", Mark Cavendish, breaks the record of another cycling great, Eddy Merckx, taking out his 35th Tour de France career stage win with a classic finish.

title.children: Cavendish eyes more stage wins after making Tour de France history

image.altText: Car on top of another vehicle in flood water.

props.synopsis: Beryl is expected to reach Jamaica at midday local time, causing an expected storm surge of 1.8 to 2.7 metres above typical levels.

title.children: Hurricane Beryl rips toward Jamaica after leaving seven people dead in the Caribbean

image.altText: A fibreglass hull pictured in the sale yard of Eaglehawk Recycle Shop

props.synopsis: Tip shops, sometimes referred to as resale sheds or treasure chest shops, can be found at dozens of locations around the country. And as Australians continue to grapple with the rising cost of living, some operators say they're seeing new customers.

title.children: This shop saves tonnes of goods from going to landfill each year, and nothing has a fixed price
